journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Associations Between Abnormal Ultrasound Color Doppler Measures and Tendon Pain Symptoms in Badminton Players During a Season
title-group.subtitle: A Prospective Cohort Study

article-meta.aff: †Institute of Sports Medicine, Bispebjerg Hospital and Center for Healthy Aging, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Copenhagen, Copenhagen, Denmark
‡The Parker Institute, Copenhagen University Hospital Frederiksberg, Copenhagen, Denmark

author-notes.corresp: *Anders Ploug Boesen, MD, Institute of Sports Medicine, Bispebjerg Hospital and Center for Healthy Aging, Faculty of Health Sciences, University of Copenhagen, Bispebjerg Bakke 23, 2400 Copenhagen NV, Denmark (e-mail: boesenanders@hotmail.com).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

abstract.p: Background: Color Doppler ultrasound is widely used to examine intratendinous flow in individuals with overuse tendon problems, but the association between color Doppler and pain is still unclear.
Hypothesis: Intratendinous flow is present and associated with pain in badminton players, and intratendinous flow and pain increase during a badminton season.
Study Design: Cohort study (prognosis); Level of evidence, 2.

Methods: Ninety-five semiprofessional badminton players were included in the study at a tournament at the start of the badminton season. All players were interviewed regarding pain. The anterior knee tendons and Achilles tendons were studied. Each tendon was scored using a quantitative grading system (grades 0-5) and a qualitative scoring system (color fraction) using color Doppler ultrasound. Eight months later, 86 of the players (91%) were retested by the same investigators during an equivalent badminton tournament (including 1032 tendon regions; 86 players with 4 tendons each with 3 regions), thus forming the study group.

Results: At the start of the season, 24 players (28%) experienced pain in 37 tendons (11%), and at the end of the season, 31 players (36%) experienced pain in 51 tendons (15%), which was a statistically significant increase (P = .0002). Abnormal flow was found in 230 tendon regions in 71 players (83%) at the start of the season compared with 78 tendon regions in 41 players (48%) at the follow-up. The decrease in abnormal flow was statistically significant (P < .0001). Of the 37 painful tendons at the start of the season, 25 had abnormal flow (68%). In contrast, 131 tendons (85%) with abnormal flow at the start of the season were pain free. At the end of the season, 18 of the 51 painful tendons (35%) had abnormal flow. Ninety-six of the 131 pain-free tendons (73%) with abnormal flow at the start of the season were normalized (no pain and normal flow) at the end of the season.

Conclusion: It was not possible to verify any association between intratendinous flow and pain at the start of the season or at the follow-up (end of the season). Intratendinous flow at the start of the season could not predict symptomatic outcome at the end of the season. The decrease in Doppler flow during the season might suggest that intratendinous flow could be part of a physiological adaptive response to loading and that intratendinous flow as previously believed is not always a sign of pathological changes.

body.p: Ultrasonography (US) has been established as an important and cost-effective tool in the diagnosis and evaluation of overuse tendon problems.3,5,41 In the last decade, the use of color Doppler US has demonstrated the presence of intratendinous flow in both degenerative patellar tendons10,12,41 and Achilles tendons.31,35,40 Although many researchers have studied vessel in-growth in the pathogenesis of overuse tendon disease, the exact role is not yet fully understood. Some studies have shown an association between the presence of intratendinous flow inside the tendons and pain in chronic midportion Achilles and patellar tendinosis,12,13,35 just as other studies have shown the presence of nerve structures in close relation to the vascular wall, indicating that in-growth of new vessels is accompanied by in-growth of nerve endings.1-3 In addition, some studies have shown that all symptomatic tendons have intratendinous flow3,35 and that detectable vascularity in the patellar tendon of volleyball players is related to an increase in pain.11,12 In contrast, recent studies show no significant correlation between intratendinous flow and symptoms.14,34,36,43 Most of these studies were using a cross-sectional study design and only examined the correlation between intratendinous flow and clinical symptoms at a single point of time,12,24,34,36 and not much information exists on what happens with the intratendinous flow and symptoms over time.11,23 These findings suggest that the area of the tendon with intratendinous flow (hyperemia) determined by the color Doppler technique could be of major importance for understanding the origins of overuse injuries in human tendons, although the association between intratendinous flow and symptoms such as pain is still unclear.

Earlier studies indicate that no flow is seen in healthy tendons with color or power Doppler,3,35 and the general belief is that the presence of intratendinous Doppler activity is a sign of pathological abnormality.3,31,40 However, recent studies have shown that intratendinous flow can be increased in both the patellar and Achilles tendons during exercise in normal healthy asymptomatic patients and in both symptomatic and asymptomatic athletes.6-8,29,34 These findings indicate that intratendinous flow is not always a sign of overuse injury, as previously stated by some authors,3,35 but instead a part of the normal physiological response to loading.6-8,29,34 Our hypothesis is that there is an association between the intratendinous flow in the Achilles and anterior knee tendons and current pain and that intratendinous flow and pain are increased in players during a badminton season.

The aim of the present study was to determine whether there is a relationship between the intratendinous flow in tendons with the presence of pain and to examine the amount of color Doppler activity and current pain in the Achilles and anterior knee tendons of semiprofessional badminton players after a badminton season (8 months). In addition, we aimed to determine if asymptomatic tendons with abnormal intratendinous flow at the start of the season lead to the development of pain at the end of the season or vice versa.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The study examined semiprofessional badminton players in the second best badminton league in Denmark who played the same 2-day national tournament at the start of the season and again at the end of the season 8 months later. The individuals who were assessed both at baseline and after 8 months were considered eligible for inclusion in the subsequent statistical analyses. The goal was to include all players participating in these 2 tournaments. The players were interviewed about previous and current pain in their Achilles and anterior knee tendons on location in the 2 tournaments, and moreover, players were examined ultrasonographically.

Ninety-five players participating in the badminton tournament at the start of the season were recruited and interviewed about pain symptoms as well as examined with US before their first match. The same examinations were repeated at an equivalent badminton tournament 8 months later at the end of the season on 86 of the original 95 players (86/95, 91%). These 86 players form the study group.

sec.title: Interview
sec.p: The interview covered demographics, injuries, and diseases. A systematic interview guide was used. The players were asked to describe the amount of competition and training during the season and the previous 3 years. Specifically, the players were questioned about current and previous pain in the Achilles tendon region and the anterior knee tendons (the quadriceps and patellar tendons) in the last 3 years and about previous diagnoses. Episodes of pain were defined as pain in a degree that had limited the amount of training for more than a week. The same 2 investigators in one room performed all interviews. All US examinations on both occasions were performed by the same 5 experienced specialists in US in another room in a blinded fashion.

sec.title: Ultrasonography
sec.p: The US examinations were performed on 4 GE Logic 9 14-MHz linear array transducers (Fairfield, Connecticut). All 5 investigators applied minimum transducer pressure during scanning to demonstrate as much flow as possible. All machines had the same settings and Doppler sensitivity. To maximize sensitivity for any flow, the lowest pulse repetition frequency and wall filter were applied. The color Doppler (CD) gain was set just below the level that produced random noise in the image. The Doppler settings were the same for all examinations. We chose CD and not power Doppler (PD) because the equipment in this study has higher sensitivity using the CD mode than with the PD mode. The Achilles tendons were scanned with the players placed prone with a pillow under the distal tibia. The feet were hanging freely in a relaxed, slightly plantarflexed position. The anterior knee tendons were scanned with the player in a supine position and the knee in 15° of flexion with a pillow (relaxed position). All tendons were scanned in the longitudinal and transverse planes.11,23,37 The tendons and peritendinous tissues were evaluated with CD, and the presence of intratendinous flow (ie, intratendinous vascularity) was registered.37,42 A longitudinal image with the maximum flow on CD was obtained to make a quantification of intratendinous CD. All scans were performed before warm-up before the players played their first match in the 2 tournaments. All data were stored as a DICOM file (National Electrical Manufacturers Association, Rosslyn, Virginia) and exported to a computer for postprocessing analysis.

sec.title: Classification of the Tendon Areas (Anatomy)
sec.p: As in recent studies, the Achilles tendon was divided into midtendon, preinsertional, and insertional (calcaneal) regions.6,7 The knee tendons were subdivided in 3 regions: quadriceps, patella, and tuberositas tibiae region.6,29 The Achilles tendon and the anterior knee tendons were scanned on both sides, giving a total of 12 tendon regions (4 tendons each with 3 tendon regions) in each player.

sec.title: Region of Interest (ROI) and Grading
sec.p: The tendons were evaluated according to the amount of intratendinous CD activity inside the ROI. In all locations, the ROI was 2 cm in the longitudinal direction. The ROI was defined according to bony landmarks except the free midtendon of the Achilles tendon, where the ROI is defined from the center of the maximum CD activity and 1 cm proximally and distally from that point. The ROIs in the Achilles and anterior knee tendons used in this study were the same as those used by other authors in recent studies (Figure 1).6,7,29 The amount of color fraction inside the ROI was calculated as the number of color pixels divided by the total number of pixels inside the ROI (Figure 1).

caption.p: Examples of quantitative grading and color fraction (CF) inside the region of interest (ROI). All ROIs are 2 cm long. The CF is the percentage of color inside the ROI. Grade 0, no Doppler activity; grade 1, 1 or 2 tiny foci; grade 2, <5% color inside ROI; grade 3, 5% to 24% color inside ROI; grade 4, 25% to 49% color inside ROI; and grade 5, ≥50% color inside ROI. (A) Quadriceps tendon. The ROI extends 1 cm proximal to and 1 cm distal to the top of the patella. (B) Patellar tendon. The ROI extends 0.5 cm proximal and 1.5 cm distal from the apex of the patella. (C) Insertion on the tibial tuberosity. The ROI extends 1 cm proximal and 1 cm distal to the first bone contact. (D) Achilles midtendon. The ROI extends 1 cm proximal and 1 cm distal to the center of maximum Doppler activity. (E) Achilles tendon preinsertion. The ROI extends 2 cm proximal to the top of the calcaneus. (F) Achilles insertion. The ROI extends 2 cm inferior to the top of the calcaneus.

sec.p: The grading system used in this study is identical to the system used by Boesen et al6 in a recent study looking at elite badminton players (Figure 1). As studies have shown that there is some degree of CD activity in normal tendons after exercise, which is probably physiological,6,7,29 CD activity 0 and 1 were characterized as normal and CD activity >1 as pathological. The tendons were assessed for CD activity at the start of the season and again 8 months later (end of the season) at the same tournament. The legs were divided into dominant and nondominant instead of left and right, according to the racket arm: For right-handed players, the right leg was the dominant and vice versa. The study was approved by the Regional Ethical Committee of Copenhagen (KF:01-045/03).

sec.title: Statistical Methods
sec.p: The analysis of correlated data arising from repeated measurements and multiple body parts (tendons and regions) when the measurements are assumed to be multivariate normal statistically calls for the use of a hierarchical model. When the outcome measure is discrete (ie, either binary or polytomous), the generalized linear mixed model (GLMM) fits statistical models to data with correlations or nonconstant variability, where the response is not normally distributed. In the model, badminton player is applied as a random effect factor, whereas tendon, region, and side (dominant vs nondominant) are applied as fixed factors. Likewise, when modeling the data over time, a fixed factor for time is applied. As it was anticipated that some different patterns could apply across participants having abnormal CD US without pain, and vice versa, we also report the actual count data from the marginal model using the total numbers of assessment in the denominator, although without estimation of any statistical inference parameters.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Basic characteristics of the players are outlined in Table 1. All players entering the tournament at the start of the season and again at the end of the season were recruited. Of the 86 players who completed the follow-up, a total of 344 tendons were scanned (86 players × 4 tendons; Achilles and anterior knee tendons on both sides in each player). This resulted in 1032 anatomic tendon regions (344 tendons × 3 tendon regions; the Achilles tendon was divided into midtendon, preinsertional, and insertional [calcaneal] regions, and the anterior knee tendons were divided into quadriceps, patellar, and tuberositas tibiae regions) applicable in the US assessments.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values shown as mean ± standard deviation unless otherwise indicated.

sec.title: Current Pain Symptom and Development
sec.p: At the start of the season, 24 players (24/86, 28%) had current pain in 37 tendons (37/344, 11%) entering the tournament; 10 players (10/86, 12%) had pain in more than one tendon. Of these 37 painful tendons, 7 Achilles tendons (3 on the dominant side; 4 on the nondominant side) and 30 anterior knee tendons (20 on the dominant side; 10 on the nondominant side) were painful (Table 2). At the end of the season, 31 players (31/86, 36%) had current pain in 51 tendons (51/344, 15%); 16 players (16/86, 19%) had pain in more than one tendon. Of these 51 tendons, 20 Achilles tendons (13 on the dominant side; 7 on the nondominant side) and 31 anterior knee tendons (20 on the dominant side; 11 on the nondominant side) were painful (Table 2). The overall increase in number of players with painful tendons from the start to the end of the season, primarily driven by changes in the Achilles tendons, was statistically significant (P = .0002). This is illustrated in Table 2, counting the number of new players developing pain symptoms during the season; there was a significant interaction between tendon × side × time (P = .0079).

caption.p: Pain at Start/End of Season: Completer Group (N = 86)

tr.th: Tendons in 24 Players With Pain at Start (Baseline)
Tendons in 31 Players With Pain at End (After)
Proportion With a Change From Baseline
No. of New Tendons With Pain (After vs Baseline)

sec.title: Intratendinous Flow
sec.p: At the start of the season, abnormal flow (grades 2-5) was observed in 71 of 86 players (71/86, 83%) in a total of 156 tendons (156/344, 45%). When looking at the different tendon regions, a total of 230 tendon regions (230/1032, 22%) had abnormal flow (Table 3) at the start of the season. At the end of the season, the abnormal flow was observed in 41 of the 86 players (41/86, 48%) in a total of 61 tendons (61/344, 18%). Abnormal intratendinous flow in the different regions was lower after the season, corresponding to 78 tendon regions (78/1032, 8%) (Table 3). This was also supported by a statistically highly significant lower number of tendon regions with abnormal flow after the season compared with the start of the season (P < .0001) using the GLMM approach. Looking at the color fraction (CF) measured as the color pixel inside the ROI at the start to the end of the season, the mean CF decreased in all tendon regions apart from the insertion region of the dominant Achilles tendon and the midportion of the nondominant Achilles tendon (see the Appendix, available in the online version of this article at http://ajs.sagepub.com/supplemental/).

caption.p: Abnormal Flow (Grade ≥2) at Start/End of Season: Completer Group (N = 86)

tr.th: Tendon Regions With Abnormal Flow at Start (Baseline)
Tendon Regions With Abnormal Flow at End (After)
New Tendon Regions With Abnormal Flow (After vs Baseline)

sec.title: Abnormal Flow and Pain
sec.p: At the start of the season, 12 players (14 %) were pain free and had normal intratendinous flow. Abnormal flow (grades 2-5) at the start of the season was seen in 156 of the total 344 tendons (156/344, 45%), and current pain was found as mentioned earlier in 37 tendons (37/344, 11%). Of these 37 painful tendons, 25 had abnormal flow (25/37, 68%). In contrast, 131 tendons with abnormal flow were found to be pain free (131/155, 85%), with no difference between the different tendons (Table 4). No association was found at the start of the season between tendons with abnormal flow and current pain.

caption.p: Association Between Pain and Intratendinous Flow

sec.p: At the end of the season, 31 players (31/86, 36%) were found to be pain free, having normal intratendinous flow, and fewer tendons had abnormal flow, with 61 of 344 tendons (61/344, 18%) with only 18 having pain (18/61, 30%) (Table 4). Pain was found in 51 tendons (51/344, 15%), of which only 18 had abnormal flow (18/51, 35%). No association was found at the end of the season between tendons with abnormal flow and current pain. During this 8-month follow-up, with the number of tendons in players with no current pain and abnormal flow initially (131 tendons), 96 tendons (96/131, 73%) were normalized (no pain and normal flow) at the end of the season. Also, players with current pain but normal flow at the start of the season (12 tendons) were reduced to 7 (7/12, 58%) painful tendons with normal flow at the end of the season. Only one tendon with current pain but normal flow at the start of the season (1/12, 8%) had developed abnormal flow but was pain free at the end of the season (Table 4). These findings also indicate no association between abnormal flow and pain.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study on semiprofessional badminton players showed a significant decrease in intratendinous flow in nearly all regions in the Achilles and anterior knee tendons during a single season (8-month period). Only 17% of the players had “normal” intratendinous flow (ie, no visual flow) at the start of the season compared with 52% at the end of the season. The decrease in intratendinous flow in the players during the season was evenly distributed throughout the tendon regions. In contrast, a significant increase in tendon pain among the players was seen during the season primarily in the Achilles tendons. Furthermore, no association was found between tendons with intratendinous flow and current pain neither at the beginning nor at the end of the season. Thus, it was not possible to confirm the hypothesis regarding a clear association between CD and pain.

Overuse tendon injury (tendinopathy) is a major problem among athletes performing explosive extensions of the knee and repetitive loading activities involving rapid forward lunges, as seen in different types of sports, for example, badminton.9,15-17,26,32 The most severe overuse injuries in badminton are tendon related, especially involving the Achilles and patellar tendons.7,15-17,26,29,32 Overused tendons are diagnosed clinically based on a combination of gradual onset of pain during loading, morning stiffness, localized swelling, and inability to perform strenuous activity,20,25 and overloading is believed to be essential in the development of tendinopathy.22,38 Despite the extent of the problem, relatively little is known about the cause and pathogenesis in tendinopathy, although many predisposing factors have been suggested but still need to be clarified.18,19,21,25,27,38 Most of the histological findings in tendinopathy represent chronic degeneration (rather than inflammation) with irregular fiber structure and increased mucoid ground substance, commonly accompanied by neovascularization (in-growth of vessels), and microtears of the tendinous tissue.3,21,27,28,38

Looking at the association between intratendinous flow and pain among semiprofessional players in our study, a significant decrease in intratendinous flow in almost all tendon regions of the Achilles and anterior knee tendons was found over the season. Despite the decrease in intratendinous flow, a number of previously normal tendons throughout the regions developed pain. At the start of the season, abnormal intratendinous flow in at least one tendon region was found in the majority of the players (83%). Accordingly, 68% of the painful tendons at the start of the season had abnormal intratendinous flow, whereas 85% of the tendons with abnormal intratendinous flow at the start of the season were pain free.

After the season, abnormal intratendinous flow was only found in 18% of all tendons, despite an increase in the number of tendons with pain. Only 35% of the tendons with pain at the end of the season had abnormal flow. Thus, these data do not support an association between abnormal intratendinous flow and pain.

Doppler activity and pain have been investigated in symptomatic and asymptomatic tendons both in sedentary individuals and athletes.** Earlier studies indicate that there is a correlation between Doppler and pain,2,3,11,12,35,41 and some even suggest that intratendinous flow is pathological.2,3,35 An earlier study in volleyball players found that the amount of intratendinous flow in the patellar tendon was associated with the presence and intensity of pain, and no tendons with normal gray-scale US findings were found to have intratendinous flow in that study.12 The same group demonstrated a positive correlation between intratendinous flow and pain score (visual analog scale [VAS] score) in the patellar tendon in a group of volleyball players during a 5-month season period.11 This is supported by a study on a small sample of basketball players.42 However, only players with abnormal intratendinous flow were included in the study.11

In healthy sedentary individuals, it has been shown that unaccustomed exercise leads to an increase in intratendinous flow in the Achilles tendon without the formation of pain.8 The increase in intratendinous flow was also found in the Achilles and anterior knee tendons in 46 elite badminton players during a tournament, and no clear significant correlation between the increase in intratendinous flow and pain among the players was found, although a tendency to a correlation between self-reported pain and the highest amount of intratendinous flow in the patellar tendon could be found.7,29 However, no threshold in the amount of intratendinous flow could be established to distinguish between painful and nonpainful anterior knee tendons.7,29 Furthermore, elite badminton players were followed during a tournament, and intratendinous flow was increased in all players after 1 or 2 matches with no association to pain.6 Another recent study looked at Doppler activity in 61 badminton players and also found no association with pain but an association with the number of training hours per week, suggesting that flow may be a response to mechanical load.34 This is supported by the present results and indicates that intratendinous flow is not always a sign of a pathological disorder but rather a part of a normal physiological adaptive loading response. A study followed 22 elite junior volleyball players during a 3-year period and found no significant correlation between clinical symptoms and abnormal gray-scale US and vascularity changes.23 The result showed that players with normal clinical test and US findings at the start of the study were associated with a low risk of developing symptoms or abnormal US findings during the 3-year follow-up period.23 This fits nicely with the present results, in which the majority of the tendons that were found to have normal flow at the start of the season still had normal flow after 8 months. The same group of volleyball players was matched with sedentary controls. Analysis of the clinical symptoms and intratendinous flow showed that these symptoms were more common among volleyball players but that still a relatively high number of asymptomatic tendons in both groups demonstrated intratendinous flow.24 These studies taken together indicate that athletes have a higher amount of intratendinous flow compared with sedentary individuals.

In some studies, the relationship between intratendinous flow and pain has been found to correlate,3,13,35 and based on biopsies from Achilles tendinopathy patients, vasculoneural in-growth has been suggested to be partly responsible for the formation of pain.3 Along this line, the presence of glutamate, a mediator of pain in the central nervous system, in the painful and hypervascularized area has also been demonstrated in chronic painful Achilles tendinopathies.4 However, this study only included 4 patients with a painful nodule in the Achilles tendon and compared them with 5 patients with normal Achilles tendons, and it does not explain asymptomatic tendons with intratendinous flow or vice versa, as other studies have now shown.8,22,34

In the present study, only 5% of the 131 pain-free tendons with abnormal intratendinous flow at the start of the season developed pain and still had abnormal flow at the end of the season. The majority (73%) of the 131 pain-free tendons with abnormal intratendinous flow at the start of the season normalized (no pain and normal flow) at the end of the season, and 92% of tendons with pain but normal intratendinous flow had not developed abnormal intratendinous flow at the end of the season. Thus, it was not possible to confirm the second hypothesis, namely, that pain-free tendons with abnormal intratendinous flow at the start of the season would develop pain during the season or vice versa. This indicates that abnormal intratendinous flow with no pain at the start of a season is not a predictor of injury during the next 8 months. The increase in intratendinous flow at the start of the season compared with the end of the season may also be a normal physiological response to intensified training. This fits well with the fact that the majority of the players in the present study had intensified their training a few weeks before the first measurements, explaining the high number of tendons with intratendinous flow, and during the season, the players (tendons) get used to the training load.

In clinical practice, clinicians only see symptomatic patients with potential increased flow and pain. Furthermore, CD is used in clinical practice to follow different treatment regimens on tendinopathy. Looking at the present players with current tendon pain at the start of the season, 68% of the tendons had abnormal intratendinous flow (grades 2-5). However, at the end of the season, only 35% of the tendons with current pain demonstrated abnormal intratendinous flow. Thus, even in the players experiencing pain, no clear association between intratendinous flow and current pain could be verified. The pain tolerance for our participants (competitive semiprofessional athletes) is probably higher compared with that in sedentary individuals. Earlier studies showed a high number of elite badminton players played with tendon pain and accepted playing with pain as part of the game.7,29 This is important to have in mind in the clinician’s everyday practice: the anticipation of pain tolerance and US findings between athletes and sedentary individuals.

In this study, the anterior knee tendons were scanned with the knee flexed 15°. The tendons are slightly strained in that position, and intratendinous flow is thereby limited.30 The correct position to examine intratendinous flow with CD is with the knee fully extended and relaxed, which we did not know when the study was performed. If we had used the fully extended and relaxed position, we expect that we would have found even more intratendinous Doppler activity also in tendons apparently without flow in this study. Therefore, we may have underestimated the amount of intratendinous flow in the patellar tendon in this study. Finally, US equipment is becoming more sensitive along with lower costs on high-end equipment. We speculate that Doppler US now identifies some of the normal flow in the tendons, which was not possible on older machines. Therefore, grading systems also need to be modified accordingly.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: There was no association between intratendinous flow in the Achilles and anterior knee tendons and current pain at the start of the season or at follow-up 8 months later (end of the season). Intratendinous flow did not predict symptomatic outcome during an 8-month-long badminton season. The decrease in Doppler activity over the season may suggest that intratendinous flow is part of a physiological adaptive response to load and is not always pathological. Our data challenge the use of CD as the main indicator used by many clinicians to evaluate the severity of tendinopathy or the prognosis of tendinopathy especially in athletes. Further data to support these findings are necessary.

fn.p: One or more of the authors has declared the following potential conflict of interest or source of funding: Funding was received from GE and Oak Foundation.
